p: Subjecting Globodera to a fluctuating diurnal heat stress from 17.5 to 32.5°C for seven days during 4–5 weeks after addition of J2 to the soil did not significantly affect their final number of eggs compared to the control grown at a constant 17.5°C. Females of G. pallida collected from plants subjected to the heat stress had a significantly smaller mean size of 0.133 ± 0.010 mm 2 compared to the control of 0.176 ± 0.007 mm 2 at one but not at two weeks after their return to 17.5°C ( p < .05 and p = .29, respectively). No corresponding similar effect was detected for G. rostochiensis at either time point.
